chapterTitle: Financial Statements, Taxes, and Cash Flow

columns.text: In this problem, we are required to describe Sunset Boardsâ€™s cash flows for 2018.

Before we begin, let us first define cash flow:

**Cash flow** is the net amount of cash and cash equivalents moving in and out of a company during a period of time.

## 1.a. Income statement for 2017 

The income statement for 2017 would look like this:

$$ 
\bold{Sunset~Boards~}\\ 
\bold{Income~Statement}\\ 
\bold{For~ the ~Year~ Ended~ 2017}\\ $$

$$\begin{array}{cccc}\\
\begin{aligned}
&\text{Sales}&&&\text{\$501,441.00}&\\
&\text{Less: Cost of Goods Sold}&&&\text{255,605.00}&\\
&\text{ Selling and Administrative}&&&\text{50,268.00}&\\
&\text{ Depreciation}&&&\underline{\text{~~~~~~~~72,158.00}}&\\
&\text{EBIT}&&&{\$~123,410.00}\\ 
&\text{Less: Interest}&&&\underline{~~~~~~~~~~15,687.00}&\\
&\text{EBT}&&&107,723.00&\\
&\text{Less: Taxes (21\%)}&&&\underline{~~~~~~~~~~22,621.83}&\\
&\bold{Net~Income}&&&{\boxed{\bold{\$~85,101.17 }}}\\

\end{aligned}
\end{array}$$
\
The net income for 2017 is $85,101.17.

## 1.b. Income statement for 2018

The income statement for 2018 would look like this:

$$ 
\bold{Sunset~Boards~}\\ 
\bold{Income~Statement}\\ 
\bold{For~ the ~Year~ Ended~ 2018}\\ $$

$$\begin{array}{cccc}\\
\begin{aligned}
&\text{Sales}&&&\text{\$611,224.00}&\\
&\text{Less: Cost of Goods Sold}&&&\text{322,742.00}&\\
&\text{ Selling and Administrative}&&&\text{65,610.00}&\\
&\text{ Depreciation}&&&\underline{\text{~~~~~~~~81,559.00}}&\\
&\text{EBIT}&&&{\$~141,313.00}\\ 
&\text{Less: Interest}&&&\underline{~~~~~~~~~~17,980.00}&\\
&\text{EBT}&&&123,333.00&\\
&\text{Less: Taxes (21\%)}&&&\underline{~~~~~~~~~~25,899.93}&\\
&\bold{Net~Income}&&&{\boxed{\bold{\$~97,433.07}}}\\

\end{aligned}
\end{array}$$
\
The net income for 2018 is $97,433.07.

## 2.a. Balance sheet for 2017

The balance sheet for 2017 would look like this:

$$ 
\bold{Sunset~Boards~}\\ 
\bold{Balance~Sheet}\\ 
\bold{For~ the ~Year~ Ended~ 2017}\\ $$

$$\begin{array}{cccc}\\
\begin{aligned}
&\text{Cash}&&&\text{\$36,884}&\\
&\text{Accounts Receivable}&&&\text{26,136}&\\
&\text{Inventory}&&&\underline{\text{~~~~~~~~50,318}}&\\
&\text{Current~Assets}&&&{\$~113,338}\\ \\

&\text{Net fixed assets}&&&\underline{\text{~~~~~~~~318,345}}&\\
&\bold{Total~Assets}&&&{\boxed{\bold{\$~431,683}}}\\ \\

&\text{Accounts Payable}&&&\$26,186&\\
&\text{Notes Payable}&&&\underline{~~~~~~~~~~29,712}&\\
&\text{Current~Liabilities}&&&\$~55,898\\ \\

&\text{Long-term debt}&&&\underline{~~~~~~~~~~160,689}&\\
&\text{Total~Liabilities}&&&\$~216,587\\ \\

&\text{Owner's equity}&&&\underline{\text{~~~~~~215,096 }}&\\
&\bold{Total~Liabilities~and~Equity}&&&{\boxed{\bold{\$~431,683 }}}
\end{aligned}
\end{array}$$
\
Owner's equity is the residual amount of total assets minus total liabilities.

## 2.b. Balance sheet for 2018

The balance sheet for 2018 would look like this:

$$ 
\bold{Sunset~Boards~}\\ 
\bold{Balance~Sheet}\\ 
\bold{For~ the ~Year~ Ended~ 2018}\\ $$

$$\begin{array}{cccc}\\
\begin{aligned}
&\text{Cash}&&&\text{\$55,725}&\\
&\text{Accounts Receivable}&&&\text{33,901}&\\
&\text{Inventory}&&&\underline{\text{~~~~~~~~67,674}}&\\
&\text{Current~Assets}&&&{\$~157,300}\\ \\

&\text{Net fixed assets}&&&\underline{\text{~~~~~~~~387,855}}&\\
&\bold{Total~Assets}&&&{\boxed{\bold{\$~545,155}}}\\ \\

&\text{Accounts Payable}&&&\$44,318&\\
&\text{Notes Payable}&&&\underline{~~~~~~~~~~32,441}&\\
&\text{Current~Liabilities}&&&\$~76,759\\ \\

&\text{Long-term debt}&&&\underline{~~~~~~~~~~175,340}&\\
&\text{Total~Liabilities}&&&\$~252,099\\ \\

&\text{Owner's equity}&&&\underline{\text{~~~~~~293,056 }}&\\

\end{aligned}

\
Owner's equity is the residual amount of total assets minus total liabilities.

## 3.a. Operating cash flow for 2017 

Operating cash flow for 2017 should be computed as follows:

$$\begin{aligned}
\textbf{Operating cash flow}& = \text{EBIT + Depreciation - Taxes}\\ \\
&=\$123,410.00 + 72,158.00 -  22,621.83\\ \\
&=\boxed{\$172,946.17}\\
\end{aligned}$$
\
In conclusion, the operating cash flow for 2017 is $172,946.17.

## 3.b. Operating cash flow for 2018

Operating cash flow for 2018 should be computed as follows:

$$\begin{aligned}
\textbf{Operating cash flow}& = \text{EBIT + Depreciation - Taxes}\\ \\
&=\$141,313.00 + 81,559.00 -  25,899.93\\ \\
&=\boxed{\$196,972.07}\\
\end{aligned}$$
\
In conclusion, the operating cash flow for 2018 is $196,972.07.

## 4. Cash flow from assets for 2018

Before we can determine the cash flow from assets, first we need to determine the net capital spending:

$$\begin{array}{l r}\\
\text{Net Fixed Assets, Ending}& \$387,855\\
\text{Less: Net Fixed Assets, Beginning} & 318,345\\
\text{Add: Depreciation} & 81,559\\  \hline
\textbf{Net Capital Spending}&\boxed{\$151,069}\\ \\
\end{array}$$

Next is to determine the changes in net working capital for 2017:

$$\begin{array}{l r}\\
\text{Current Assets}& \$113,338\\
\text{Less: Current Liabilities} & 55,898\\ \hline
\textbf{Net Working Capital}&\boxed{\$57,440}\\ \\
\end{array}$$

Also, we need determine the changes in net working capital for 2018:

$$\begin{array}{l r}\\
\text{Current Assets}& \$157,300\\
\text{Less: Current Liabilities} & 76,759\\ \hline
\textbf{Net Working Capital}&\boxed{\$80,541}\\ \\
\end{array}$$

Now we can already determine changes in net working capital:

$$\begin{array}{l r}\\
\text{Net Working Capital - 2018}& \$80,541\\
\text{Less: Net Working Capital - 2017} & 57,440\\ \hline
\textbf{Changes in Net Working Capital}&\boxed{\$23,101}\\ \\
\end{array}$$

Finally, to determine the cash flow from assets for 2018:
$$\begin{array}{l r}\\
\text{Operating cash flow}& \$196,972.07\\
\text{Less: Net Capital Spending} & 151,069.00\\ 
\text{Less: Changes in Net Working Capital} & 23,101.00\\ \hline
\textbf{Cash flow from assets}&\boxed{\$22,802.07}\\ \\
\end{array}$$
\
In conclusion, the cash flow from assets for 2018 is $22,802.07.

## 5. Cash flow to creditors for 2018

Before we can determine the cash flow to creditors for 2018, first we should determine the net new borrowing:

$$\begin{array}{l r}\\
\text{Long-term debt, ending}& \$175,340\\
\text{Less: Long-term debt, beginning} & 160,689\\ \hline
\textbf{Net new borrowing}&\boxed{\$14,651}\\ \\
\end{array}$$

Now we can already determine the cash flow to creditors for 2018:

$$\begin{aligned}
\textbf{Cash flow to creditors}& = \text{Interest paid - Net new borrowing} \\ \\
&=\$17,980 - \$14,651 \\ \\
&=\boxed{\$3,329}\\
\end{aligned}$$
\
In conclusion, the cash flow to creditors for 2018 is $3,329.

## 6. Cash flow to stockholders for 2018

Before we can determine the cash flow to stockholders for 2018, first we should determine the additions to retained earnings:


$$\begin{array}{l r}\\
\text{Net income}& \$97,433.07\\
\text{Less: Dividends (40\% of net income)} & 38,973.23\\ \hline
\textbf{Additions to Retained Earnings}&\boxed{\$58,459.84}\\ \\
\end{array}$$

Next is to determine the dividends paid:
$$\begin{aligned}
\textbf{Dividends paid}& = \text{Net income - Additions to retained earnings} \\ \\
&=\$97,433.07 - \$58,459.84 \\ \\
&=\boxed{\$38,973.23}\\
\end{aligned}$$

Finally, the cash flow to stockholders for 2018 should be computed as follows:

$$\begin{aligned}
\textbf{Cash flow to stockholders}& = \text{Dividends paid - Net new equity raised} \\ \\
&=\$38,973.23 - \$19,500.00 \\ \\
&=\boxed{\$19,473.23}\\
\end{aligned}$$
\
In conclusion, the cash flow to stockholders for 2018 is $19,473.23.

Sunset Boards earns enough profit to run the business but a huge amount of operating cash flows is used in capital spending. If Sunset Boards wants to enter in the new project, then they need to raise more funds from the external financing sources such as creditors, banks, or new stockholders. Although this would be an aggressive strategy for Sunset Boards, they need additional investments for its growth and sustainability before entering on an expansion plan.
